question: Kelly.
answer: Kevin, hey.

question: Hi. Listen. Could I steal you a second?
answer: Absolutely.

question: I had a great time last night. Again.
answer: Me too. That's not what you came to say.

question: You work for me. I'm not comfortable with-- y'know, "us"...
answer: I was working for you when "us" started, what's--

question: I know and I thought I could handle it but work and pleasure along with somebody else, it's a dangerous mix.
answer: Kevin, as long as we... What was that last part?

question: The somebody else part?
answer: Yeah, that part. There's... somebody who's um...

question: Else.
answer: Oh. Oh. That's okay. Well. This uh... this probably wasn't meant to be, y'know. I mean, I'm... God, I gotta be ten years younger and you, you... you're y'know...

question: A jerk.
answer: Oh... No, no, I'm not angry I'm not, I'm just thrown, I'm... I actually have an early lunch, so...

question: It's ten after nine.
answer: Yes, well... famished.

question: What do you expect, mugging me from behind?
answer: I tapped you.

question: Well you shouldn't have. How did you even know where I was.
answer: Wild guess.

question: I don't like to be scared, Myra, I have a thing about fright, don't ever scare me.
answer: Kevin told me you were upset.

question: Really? I never realized he was so psychic, how could he detect that, did he tell you there's somebody else?
answer: Well... he didn't have to tell me that part.

question: You?
answer: It started before you, Kelly, I never would've--

question: You?
answer: It was just a quick thing which we thought was over, and and...

question: You and Kevin.
answer: It wasn't suppose to happen, I don't know what to say...

question: You don't know what to say, lucky for you action speaks louder than words.
answer: Kelly--

question: I'm not upset, Myra, okay. I just never thought of you as a y'know...
answer: Backstabber?

question: No.
answer: Liar?

question: Myra.
answer: Shitbutt?

question: Hey.
answer: Kevin. How's it going, what's happenin', family good, great, nice to catch up, get out.

question: This is business. There was an accident in Maine, some guy got killed by something in a lake. Probably a bear, but... they found a tooth.
answer: A tooth?

question: A tooth they say couldn't have come from any bear. They say it looks prehistoric. Like maybe a dinosaur.
answer: Oh, well then I'm sure that's it, he got killed by a dinosaur, anything else?

question: I want you to go there.
answer: Sorry?

question: I'm sure it's nothing, but you're a paleontologist, this is what we do, I--
answer: This is what we do?

question: I'd like you to check out this lake. See--
answer: Are you on drugs?

question: Kelly--
answer: I'm not going to Maine, I won't even go west of Forty-third Street--

question: Part of our research--
answer: I'm not even a field person.

question: Well on this one I'd like you to be.
answer: This was Myra's idea, wasn't it? Get me out of the office for a few days, until--

question: It has nothing to do with--
answer: I never do field work and even if I did, Maine, to look at a tooth of a dinosaur who bit somebody, couldn't you dream up something--

question: Kelly--
answer: I am not going to Maine. That's ridiculous.

question: I am not going to Maine. That's ridiculous.
answer: He just came up screaming.

question: Did he say anything?
answer: He just kinda gurgled. He was pretty much dead.

question: And you didn't see anything?
answer: The lake was dead calm until up he came. The tooth is in there.

question: There? That's the morgue.
answer: Yes.

question: Is the dead guy in there?
answer: That's where they keep them. You want me to bring the tooth out here?

question: Um. No, no. Let's go. I need to get a microscopic look at it. Maybe I should see...
answer: I wouldn't.

question: I'm fine, thank you.
answer: Have you ever seen a dead body before, Ms. Scott?

question: Well. At wakes.
answer: This is a little different.

question: I can look at dead things. Wait. Okay. This... how long did this attack go on for?
answer: Seconds. Three, four.

question: And this is how he came to the boat?
answer: Yes.

question: Okay. And is there a place nearby I could go to vomit?
answer: Nobody lives within twenty-five miles, 'cept some old couple who live right on the lake. Teenagers trek in every once in a while, none have disappeared, and none have spotted anything unusual.

question: You talk to the married couple?
answer: Not yet.

question: What kind of backup do we have?
answer: We?

question: What?
answer: Sorry. I'm just a little unclear as to why the Museum of Natural History would send somebody here.

question: You have a thing against museums?
answer: I got nothing against--

question: Ever even been in one? What is that?
answer: Lightweight Forward Area air device unit. Whatever's out there, one shot with this and he's dead.

question: And you stock these things for what, to fend off Russia?
answer: You're sort of a rude person.

question: Kelly Scott.
answer: Jack Wells. A museum sent you?

question: Are we all museum bigots in Maine?
answer: Did you make anything of the tooth?

question: I'll call the coroner.
answer: What is with this lake? It looks black and... there are no waves or anything.

question: They wanted to call it Lake Placid. But somebody said that name was taken.
answer: Gee.

question: The tents were sent ahead, they should already be set-up.
answer: We're staying in tents?

question: I told you. Two days, we'd have to camp.
answer: Yes, camp, I thought that meant Holiday Inn, I never heard "tents", will there be toilets?

question: What the hell?
answer: What?

question: I thought I saw...
answer: It looks like a branch.

question: Hey!!
answer: You threw it at me!!

question: I just let go of it.
answer: Don't throw heads at me, and stop calling me "Ma'am"!

question: What is going on here?
answer: How big do the bears get?

question: Big but... a bear couldn't do that to a moose or man in water. On land maybe. But...
answer: And they're sure he didn't get tangled under the outboard somehow?

question: Hank says he's sure.
answer: It really is beautiful, isn't it?

question: Never been to Maine before?
answer: I was told they discriminate against people with hygiene. I never believed it.

question: Why are you here? Really.
answer: I told you.

question: The Museum of Natural History doesn't send out investigators to--
answer: How would you know, what--

question: And even if they did, I doubt he or she would have problems with tents.
answer: So I don't like tents, why--

question: You don't like tents, mosquitos, look at your fingernails, you have about as much business being in the woods-- They sent you out to examine a tooth, why are you out here on the on the lake?
answer: I am a paleontologist. I also was dating my boss he turned out to be involved with a co-worker who was also my friend and for the sake of comfort, theirs, I was shipped off to Maine. I don't feel like going back yet. I'm not making it up.

question: Well. You don't have to stay out here, why don't--
answer: I've come, I'm here, I'm staying. Unless there are ticks. Oh my God.

question: What?
answer: If this is who I think it is. It is.

question: Who?
answer: Hector Cyr. He's a rich kook mythology professor. He's done some work with our museum. He also treks the world to swim with crocodiles.

question: You beat me. Balls. I need some of you to help me unpack. You and you. Not you. Who do we have from Fish And Game? I could see the algae blooms just coming in, how long has this lake been stagnant? Hi, Hector Cyr. The Earth is round and so should you be.
answer: --Who is he?

question: I'll need any and all topographic studies.
answer: Wait just a second. You don't just fly in here and start barking orders.

question: Even so, you're allowed to boast. You look thin by the way, I've mentally undressed you, I can see your ribcage.
answer: I really don't mean to be discourteous. But how is it a person could come to believe that a crocodile is in New England?

question: They have saltwater glands, they can swim across oceans, it's only a matter of time.
answer: And what would he do come winter?

question: They can survive winter. As long as their nostrils don't freeze, they survive, am I foolish to explain things, he had such trouble with my name? Is this where it happened?
answer: Around here. Yeah.

question: What's that?
answer: White perch.

question: Are they feeding?
answer: Doesn't look like it.

question: Some decomposition, little acidic, it has been swallowed. Is this the man who was killed?
answer: We'd only just met.

question: Well, you've got a croc alright, they're keystone species.
answer: Keystone what?

question: Baby crocs?
answer: Adult males will charge hatchlings. If there's one out there...

question: If one could be out there... why does Fish And Game tell me it's impossible?
answer: Because they just consult their little indigenous charts.

question: Listen... if you really do know crocs, you should know how stealth like they are. I wouldn't be standing a foot from the water. He could be right there and you wouldn't see him.
answer: I'd be able to see something. Oh that's funny. That was real funny.

question: And law enforcement, such dangerous work. The idea that you could die suddenly with no offspring, disconcerting, let's mate, commit your genes to perpetuity.
answer: Hey. We are here on official business.

question: Cocktail?
answer: No!! What's with digging the holes?

question: They come on land and they're brazen. They're also attracted to noise, you can see I make a lot of it.
answer: Everybody out, back to your tents, now!

question: Could she stay, we've tentatively scheduled intercourse.
answer: No!! Out! You listen to me. The only reason I'm letting you be part of this is 'cause you got the helicopter and the radar--

question: And you like me.
answer: I do not like you.

question: Deep down, gut check. I'm growing fond of you and it's liberating to say so.
answer: You're a whacko.

question: What are you doing?
answer: Skipping stones. Look how flat that water is, you can get ten skips on a good one.

question: Listen, uh... Hank and I think it best if you stay on shore.
answer: I beg your pardon?

question: Whatever's out there did flip over a canoe--
answer: I am not staying on shore.

question: It's too dangerous for--
answer: I didn't fly up here to roast marshmallows--

question: You flew up here because your boss--
answer: I am going out on that boat and why are you picking on me, is this some kind of--

question: I'm beginning to see why you were shipped off.
answer: That was an awful thing to say to me.

question: I'm sorry but you're...
answer: I do know crocodiles and I won't get in your way. I really do want to be a part of this.

question: Okay. We're up at six.
answer: Good.

question: Looking into a gun barrel. He screams. Keough screams. Then-- Jesus Christ!!
answer: What the hell are you doing?!!

question: What are you doing?!
answer: You're crawling around like a--

question: I'm laying a spring trap!
answer: A spring trap!

question: I keep telling you, they can come on land, I don't wanna wake up in the middle of the night--
answer: I coulda shot you, you--

question: Hey! What is going on?
answer: This is an official investigation, and this cuckoo bird is a civilian. I don't care how much money he's got, he's a total mental.

question: You hurt his feelings. I think you should go apologize.
answer: Apologize?

question: In his defense, every primitive culture known to man deified them. He's a mythology professor, he thinks crocs are divine conduits.
answer: Is this 'spose to make me take him more serious?

question: It's to make you understand him, with understanding comes tolerance. Too bad they don't put proverbs in Twinkies, my load would be lighter.
answer: Why does everybody insult my intelligence, I have intelligence, intelligent people eat Twinkies.

question: Was that like a homo-sexual remark?
answer: I asked you to be nice to him. He may be a kook but he's also been all over the world with them. He even swam in the Grimetti with killer Niles all around him, he never got nipped.

question: And that's why he thinks they're Godly?
answer: He said he knew it when he looked into their eyes.

question: You like Jack?
answer: What? I don't even know the guy.

question: Hector thinks you like him.
answer: Well Hector's a giant cracker.

question: You think Jack's handsome?
answer: What is this?

question: I'm just curious. I can never tell what women think is handsome. Is he handsome?
answer: Well. He's probably rugged handsome I guess. Yeah.

question: Am I?
answer: It shouldn't be taking so long.

question: You okay? Kelly?
answer: Yeah. Nobody saw anything?

question: No. U.S. Wildlife is on their way.
answer: That's probably good.

question: Police want to keep it quiet, if the press gets word... lake monster. They just want us to sit tight. Are you okay?
answer: Um... y'know... Yeah.

question: A man died. You don't have to be so tough.
answer: I'm fine. I uh... I'm fine.

question: I'm sorry. Was he a good man?
answer: Yup.

question: Whenever somebody dies I consider it such a waste that I didn't know him better.
answer: His head was just... bitten off.

question: I used to have this recurring nightmare that I was headless. I'd be on the ground looking up at my body, no head, walking around bumping into everything. And my parents wouldn't let me in the house 'cause they'd just bought all these new antique lamps and they were afraid I'd knock them over, made sense, and meanwhile, the neighborhood bullies would see my round little head on the ground looking like a ball, and they'd come rushing over to start up a game of soccer. I'd actually feel grateful just for being allowed into the contest, that's esteem for you, what are your thoughts?
answer: You know, Hector, I'm sure you're a fine person in your own mental way. But I think it would be best if you and I didn't speak.

question: This is a setback.
answer: You don't want to cut me down. 'Cause I'll kill you.

question: Hard to believe there could be a monster under such peacefulness.
answer: I thought I might track the shoreline tomorrow, look for prints. You know they say the brain confuses fear for passion.

question: Excuse me?
answer: When you get scared, the brain releases a chemical, same chemical it releases when somebody's... in high school, the thing to do was to take the girl to a scary movie.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: I'm saying between the moonlight, a beautiful lake and a monster that bites heads off... you look good.

question: Gee, that was so poetic, Jack. I'm all moist.
answer: Forgive me for trying to be nice.

question: Nice? Nice would be "you look pretty," nice is not some man- eating monster has tricked my brain into making you look good.
answer: I didn't say it like that.

question: You did, you--
answer: I was trying to pay you a compliment, I was guising it as science 'cause I know you're comfortable in that arena. Science.

question: A man just died, you're hitting on me with science.
answer: Just forget it.

question: Like little children. You okay?
answer: Yeah. I got some stuff for your cut.

question: I couldn't believe... did you see the size of that thing's mouth?
answer: I wonder if he's some kind of mutant. That bear had to be surprised.

question: Let's get away from the shore. Sorry.
answer: It's okay.

question: Ow. Shit.
answer: Just gotta pull it a little tighter.

question: Who taught you be be a nurse?
answer: Father's a surgeon. I can even stitch in a pinch, wouldn't be a bad idea here.

question: No thanks.
answer: Keep it dry. No swimming.

question: Thank you. You're having the best time of your life, aren't you?
answer: What? Why... people have been killed, I hardly think I'm having a good time, why would... Does it show? This is the first time I've actually... y'know been in the middle of anything. I've never really even gotten dirty before, with me showers have always been preventative.

question: That's why you're here. To get in the middle of something?
answer: Maybe. I've always read about what's happened. I've never... I know it sounds silly but, it's nice to be someplace while something is actually... y'know... happening. We should probably go to bed. Get rest, get some rest. Go to our separate beds, get some rest.

question: Thanks for the... bandaid.
answer: Night.

question: Just spit him back out. Some shall live, some shall die, arbitrarily, sound like any higher power we know?
answer: He didn't eat the kid cause he'd just swallowed a bear.

question: Sobek. Half man, half croc, oldest God--
answer: I'm tired, Hector. I know this because you're beginning to not bug me.

question: That sounds good but underneath it's hurtful. Nightcap?
answer: Raincheck.

question: Well. Goodnight.
answer: We seem to say goodnight a lot.

question: We could not say it and... Well, that thing is ambulatory if you want somebody in your tent to...
answer: Night.

question: I'm gonna get ticks. I know it. They're drawn to me. I got a thing about ticks.
answer: Ssssh!

question: What?
answer: I heard something.

question: It seems like we're getting lower.
answer: It happens when I land.

question: Why are we landing?
answer: 'Cause this is the cove he obviously lives in.

question: Thing we can lift it?
answer: Maybe. Don't mush it.

question: I'm not mushing it.
answer: You're mushing it a little around the--

question: Okay. Okay. Okay.
answer: That is it!!

question: Really--
answer: No. I keep getting hit with heads!

question: Calm down.
answer: You calm down!

question: Calm down.
answer: I'm being very calm. I'm composed. This is the second time I've been hit with a severed head, I'm entitled to complain.

question: He went swimming.
answer: Oh.... my. I suddenly feel a bit foolish. You're different from the others. Holy spirit of Sobek. Holy ghost. Holy shit.

question: Hector!!
answer: Just turn the ignition, it's fuel injected.

question: Come on.
answer: I know under the circumstances, biting off my head might seem viable. It would cheapen you.

question: I might get a shot.
answer: No. If you don't kill him instantly, I'm dead and you'll only kill him instantly if you get his brain, which is about the size of a cherry. And even if you were on target, a bullet might not penetrate his hide.

question: I'm a civilian! You don't have any authority--
answer: I can arrest you!!

question: Then do it!!
answer: You probably do want to be killed by it, that was you trying to meet your maker.

question: So profound and fat.
answer: Did you want to be killed by it?

question: You think I'm that nuts?
answer: Hector. What you just did... there was at least some sort of a death wish going on.

question: Nothing's real.
answer: Excuse me?

question: Nothing's real. I'm rich, people are automatically my friends, sycophants ooze out like oil slicks and and and-- With crocodiles... everything's even.
answer: I'm no psychiatrist. But I would think there have to be better places to look for autonomy, than--

question: I'm an empty man, Kelly, wealth has robbed me of the dream in life, I sit here broken, a hollow sack--
answer: Oh, bullshit.

question: Didn't even sound good?
answer: No.

question: Eh. Fuck it.
answer: Can I tell them you won't go back in the water?

question: Yes. You may. But maybe... I don't know...
answer: What?

question: Forget about him being God, he's thirty feet long, he is a miracle of nature, who somehow made his way to Maine. This is a grand beast. A grand dragon. An attempt should at least be made to capture him alive.
answer: Well, you can try talking them into that, if--

question: I have enough flaxedil with me to put him out. And I think I know a way to--
answer: Forget it.

question: We lure him on land and pump him with the drugs.
answer: No way.

question: Jack. We've all seen it. He's probably a hundred and fifty years old, he's bigger than an elephant.
answer: So maybe Wildlife will try to save him, they're more equipped to--

question: We both know what they'll do.
answer: Even if we could tranq him-- how would we get him on land.

question: Keep enough tension to hold him up, Hector, we don't know if he can swim.
answer: Right.

question: The more he thrashes, the better.
answer: You ready on shore?

question: If he tires, lift him out. It can't work.
answer: He has been going after everything. It could work. But this is not a happy cow.

question: He looks like a giant tea bag. He doesn't seem to be swimming. Is he swimming?
answer: He's floating. Take it home.

question: Hector.
answer: Hold on! I got something on the screen.

question: You do?
answer: He's coming.

question: Where? Where?
answer: Thirty meters or so. Moving slow, but straight toward Elsie.

question: Can you confirm visually or just radar?
answer: Radar, he's underwater. But he's definitely coming.

question: Okay. Lead him in. Okay, everybody up on the trucks. We aim for the stomach or side... there's little chance the darts will pierce his hide. Everybody up on the trucks.
answer: On our way. There, he's surfacing, there's the snout. You little sucker.

question: No!
answer: I just have this feeling everything's totally safe.

question: I see blood. Maybe you got him, Hank. I can't see him, but this is definitely blood. Maybe you got him.
answer: Where is he?!

question: I don't know!
answer: Hector!! Alright. Game over. Should I?

question: Thanks for the rescue.
answer: You take care.

question: You talk to Bickerman?
answer: She didn't tell us about the other croc 'cause she was afraid we'd blow it's head off.

question: Women's intuition. Are there anymore?
answer: Just those two. Okay. Well... I got stuff to pack up and...

question: No, no, I'll be a while anyway. I'm gonna say goodbye to the lake.
answer: You sure? I don't mind...

question: No, I actually want to stay for a little while. I'll miss you most of all scarecrow.
answer: If I'm ever in New York...

question: Yeah.
answer: Y'know, if we didn't live in separate worlds and...

question: But we do. Hey, we'll always have Maine.
answer: It was... something meeting you.

question: Likewise.
answer: I thought I should say goodbye to the lake too.

question: Different worlds, Jack.
answer: Yeah, I thought about that as I was driving... and... I haven't found somebody in my world. You found anyone in yours?

question: No.
answer: So I was thinking... maybe if I met anybody in my world who was good for you and if you know somebody in New York good for me, we could fix each other up.

question: You think?
answer: Worth a try. We don't wanna be alone forever, do we?

question: Probably not.
answer: That was... y'know if the guy asks me can she kiss, now I'll be able to tell him if you can.
